abstract.p: Improving system efficiency and reliability is motivating countries to design and execute different types of time of use demand response programs. However, certain deficiencies prevent these programs from reaching their goals. Smart meters as a mechanism could help the electric system to reach the highest demand-side management goals which are inaccessible through today’s methods. On the other hand, realization of smart meters in a system would be very costly. In this situation, identifying the most influential buses to implement the infrastructures of a smart grid is of highest importance. In this paper, after a short overview of demand response programs and problems facing them, a smart meter is introduced as a solution to these problems. As a test grid, the IEEE 57-bus network has been chosen to compare the results of the execution of a normal time of use program and real-time pricing program available in a smart grid. In order to execute the mentioned programs in this system, 10 buses have been selected as the most influential buses using a generation shift factor method. The execution of time of use and real-time pricing programs on the selected buses have been simulated using a demand response model. Finally, the time of use program and the real-time pricing program in a smart grid environment have been compared with respect to load shape modification, load factor, price curve, and ‘Expected Power Not Supplied’.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: After the deregulation which happened in the electricity industry, many utility companies have tried to influence the consumption of electricity by executing different demand response (DR) programs. Implementing a DR program correctly could have several advantages for both the utility company and electricity customers. The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) introduces its advantages as follows:1

list-item.p: - reduction of demand from expensive electricity generating units;
- prevention of occurrence of price spikes in the market;
- reduced price of electricity for consumers;

sec.p: In order to benefit from the mentioned advantages, several electric utility companies have designed different kinds of DR programs such as seasonal time of use (TOU) programs. Smart grids (SGs), as a new concept, have also been introduced to the electric industry. SGs have several advantages for the electric industry and one of the key advantages is their ability to provide the proper infrastructure for efficient execution of DR programs.2 In this paper, the IEEE 57-bus network has been chosen to study and compare the influence of both the normal TOU program and a real-time pricing (RTP) program using smart meters. In order to have the best answer, 10 buses have been selected for the execution of TOU and RTP demand response programs based on sensitivity analysis. The basis for selecting these buses is to find buses which have the greatest influences on transmission lines load reduction. Eventually, these two programs have been compared considering the load factor, electricity price and system reliability.

sec.title: 2. Demand response programs and their problems
sec.p: DR programs are divided into two main categories, time-based rates and incentive-based programs. Time-based rates define variable electricity price throughout the day. The focus of this paper is on time-based programs which rely on a customer’s choice to decrease or change their consumption in response to changes in electricity price during a 24-hour period.
Different types of DR programs include the following.
Time-based DR can be defined as the changes in electricity usage by end-use customers from their normal consumption patterns in response to changes in the price of electricity over time.3

The most important objective which has led the electric utility companies to design and execute DR programs is to provide a link between consumers and the electricity market. The lack of an effective link between market and end users has brought too many problems to the electric industries. In electricity market, customers do not have enough information and hardware to have an active role in the market. As a result, customers continue to consume electrical energy even at times of high electricity price. As a result, this behavior can lead to price crisis in electricity market (price spikes, line congestion, etc.).4

Although DR programs have advantages for the system and consumers, their successful execution could be problematic. These problems can lead to decreased social satisfaction and as a result a lack of desired response from consumers. These problems can be summarized as follows.

sec.title: 2.1. Lack of required coordination between the designed program and actual load curve
sec.p: The periods in seasonal TOU DR programs are usually adjusted once every 6 months. Actual load, however, changes more rapidly than this rate. On the other hand, it is not acceptable by the customers to change the periods and the electricity price more often than that. Therefore, the perfect coordination between periods in the TOU program and actual load curve cannot be achieved.

sec.title: 2.2. Reduced social welfare
sec.p: Time-based DR programs rely on customer’s choice to respond to electricity price changes during the day. In other words, these programs would be successful if customers shift their loads to time intervals with low energy prices and decrease their consumption during periods of high energy prices. An important issue which has been ignored by the electric utility companies and regulators is the loss of customers’ social welfare.

If the price of energy increases in a certain time interval, customers have two ways of confronting it. First, they can shift some parts of their loads to other time intervals; and second, they can decrease some of their consumption, if it is possible.

Considering the facts that shifting loads requires customers change their lifestyle and do some of their activities during inconvenient hours of day, such as late nights, and consumption decrease means not doing some desirable activities. Both decreasing the consumption and shifting loads to other time intervals cause customers to sacrifice a part of their social welfare. These problems reduce the public acceptability of DR programs since people are not willing to lose their welfare easily.

sec.title: 2.3. Inelasticity of demand
sec.p: Successful execution of TOU programs requires the customers to change their usage pattern with respect to electricity price throughout the day. This issue is highly related to the success of DR programs to the concept of elasticity of demand.5

Compared with other commodities, electricity shows a relatively lower elasticity of demand which means smaller consumption reductions and smaller load shifts would happen. In order to have a more elastic demand, customers have to shift and reduce their loads in times of high electricity prices.6 The source of inelasticity in electrical energy demand may vary dependent on region. Increase in elasticity in demand improves the result of time-based programs, which leads to better control of market price, better peak load reduction and smoother load profile.
In order to have effective and influential demand response programs, it is necessary to find solutions to the above-mentioned flaws.

sec.title: 3. Smart grid
sec.p: Nowadays smart grids are an important concept in today’s electrical energy literature. Smart grid refers to a modern and intelligent power system in which the needed information is available to both producers and consumers, and all parts of the system have sufficient information to regulate their activities.2 The U.S. Department of energy defines a smart grid as today’s grid joined by advanced metering and control devices such as:
Having these smart infrastructures, a smart grid has many advantageous characteristics including but not limited to the following.

All customers regardless of their size, are aware of instantaneous market price through high-speed connections (depending on the market, price can be settled every hour, half an hour or every quarter of an hour). By having an in-home controller connected to all of the appliances, every customer would be able to control their energy consumption automatically with respect to market price. For example, the controller can be set to increase room temperature at times of high spot prices, or to turn on washing machines at times of low spot prices (02:00 or 03:00).

In this environment, electric and hybrid vehicles would be able to act as distributed storages, storing the energy at times of low electricity prices and discharging the stored energy at times of high prices.

A smart grid enables the use of distributed generation in all voltage levels. Domestic generators such as wind turbines or photovoltaic cells would help customers to reduce their energy bills and even sell surplus electricity back to the grid. In other words, a smart grid provides customers with enough information and hardware to be able to actively participate in the electricity market.
In the following sections, the influence of a smart grid on TOU demand response programs will be demonstrated. First, influential buses are selected for implementing a smart grid’s infrastructures.

sec.title: 4. Identifying influential buses
sec.p: In order to achieve a satisfactory response at the lowest cost, the ISO should initiate a massive search to find critical buses in the system. In this paper the IEEE 57-bus network has been chosen to analyze and compare the influences of TOU programs and the RTP program enabled through the realization of a smart grid.

The most influential buses have been selected in order to execute the TOU program and also, in the next step, it has been assumed that a smart grid’s infrastructures have been installed in these buses. Owing to high price of these infrastructures only 10 buses have been selected which have a great effect on preventing transmission line congestion.

First, using contingency analysis, critical lines which are treating the system the most are identified. Then, 10 buses which could affect the critical lines tension the most have been selected. Load reduction in these buses would yield the best response to the network’s load.
To implement DR programs, buses (loads) having the highest impact on line overload and on network restoration to normal situation have been chosen.

To achieve this, as a first step, single contingencies for transmission lines have been considered. When a line is disconnected, other lines have to transmit its load. As a result some of the other lines would be overloaded. The total amount of overloading (TAO) resulting from disconnecting a line for each line has been calculated. The apparent power limit (rated apparent power) of each line is assigned as 1.2 times the power transmitted through the line during normal operation condition. Then, by multiplying TAO in the probability of the related contingency, contingencies are ranked for each line.7

GSF shows the impact of an increase in load of the ith bus on the transmitted power of the lth line. GSF could be positive or negative. sec.title: 6. First scenario: normal TOU
sec.p: An ordinary daily load of Iran’s electric network has been chosen to analyze and compare the influence of both the TOU program and RTP program enabled through smart grid technologies. The load curve belongs to 28 August 2006 of Iran’s grid.10

The load curve has been normalized based on the IEEE 57-bus system’s total load with a coefficient of 1.4. So, the average demand through this day is 1.4 times the IEEE 57-bus network’s total power. This load curve is shown in Figure 1.

The price of electricity throughout the day can be derived from the load curve by using the price curves of Gencos. The price curves of Gencos have been considered the same as price curves defined in the IEEE 57-bus system. In order to have the price of the electricity throughout the day, a DC optimal power flow has been run for each hour of the day. Using the above-mentioned method, the price curve relating to this day is shown in Figure 2. For analyzing and comparing the influences of the TOU program and RTP program in a smart grid environment, a TOU scenario is defined in this section. A typical TOU program containing three price levels is introduced with respect to the above-mentioned load curve.

sec.p: Aalami et al.9 chose greater values to study the effect of TOU programs on load curve. In this paper, however, simulating the effect of TOU program on load curve has shown considerable changes in load during off-peak and on-peak periods. As Aalami et al.9 suggest, load reductions as large as 55% could be achieved during on-peak hours. This large reduction in electricity consumption is very far from reality.
Thus, as Table 4 shows, relatively small values (about the half of values chosen by Aalami et al.9) have been chosen for elasticities of TOU programs.

sec.title: 7. Second scenario: RTP program; adaptive periods
sec.p: In this section, the influence of a smart grid on time-based DR programs has been evaluated.

In the RTP program, every time period (an hour in this paper) would have its own electricity price. By having the supply curves of Gencos, the price curve during the day could be derived from demand curve which is shown in Figure 2.

Enabled through smart infrastructures, RTP could be practically executed. In RTP program, every two different time periods has its own cross-elasticity and also every time period has a different self-elasticity. For the sake of simplicity, hours of the day have been divided into three categories as on-peak, mid-peak and off-peak. However, for modeling a RTP program, these time intervals could not be assumed as fixed periods during a day and they change depending on the load and energy price at that hour.

The technique used here is based on defining on-peak, mid-peak and off-peak periods depending on how high the electricity demand and relatively its price are. Obviously, hours with higher demand are on-peak periods and those with lower electricity demands are considered as off-peak periods. So, the periods are adaptive depending on the magnitude of demand. sec.p: The smart grid characteristics defined in Section 3 would help customers to respond to changes in electricity price and vary their energy consumption during the day more effectively. In this new environment, even the smallest customers would have the ability to participate in power market and to adjust their consumption with respect to electricity price in order to reach their desired welfare. Enabled through smart grid infrastructures, each customer would be able to install his own DG plant and to appear as a producer who sells power to the grid at times of extra production.

This means, customers are able to buy less energy from the grid at times of high prices, by shifting loads, using their own DG plant or even through discharging batteries of their hybrid electric vehicles which have been charged during the night before.

Therefore, SG characteristics can be added to DR model by increasing the self- and cross-elasticities of demand.5 Elasticities between different time intervals have been increased compared with the TOU program. The increase in self- and cross-elasticities are due to SG ability to effectively shift loads, also the influence of DG plants and distributed storage lies inside this increase. In order to simulate the effect of a smart grid on the load curve, it has been assumed that self-elasticities experience a 100% increase while cross-elasticities experience a 200% increase in the smart grid environment. sec.title: 8. Modeling scenarios and comparison
sec.p: In this section the influence of the defined TOU program and of a RTP program on the load curve are investigated.

In an actual market, changes in load lead to changes in market price. Therefore, for analyzing the effect of SG on load and price curve during a day, it must be considered that in a RTP program unlike TOU programs in which only price affects demand, demand affects the price curve as well. This is due to the ability of consumers to change their load in response to price, and this happens through interactions between demand and the supply side in real time. So, in order to derive the load curve in a smart grid environment in the presence of a RTP program, load shape should be derived in an iterative procedure.

Figure 3 shows the initial load curve, the load curve after the execution of the TOU program and the load curve using a RTP program enabled by a smart grid. Both the TOU program and the RTP program have been executed on the selected buses demonstrated in Section 4.

caption.p: Comparison between initial load curve, load curve after the execution of TOU program and load curve using a RTP program in a smart grid.

sec.p: The load curve pertaining to the smart grid shown in Figure 3 has been evaluated through four iterations which are enough for modeling the effect of SG. Further iterations would make the result be very far from the reality of the power system.

As is evident in Figure 3, the TOU DR program has slightly helped the load curve to become smoother. On the other hand, RTP in a smart grid environment has made the load curve smoother and has successfully reformed it.

sec.p: The load factor related to the load curve after executing TOU program clearly explains the limits of this program in reforming the load curve. Therefore, this program would not yield the desired result. Problems discussed in Section 2 would prevent the TOU program to reach to its predetermined goals.
As it can be seen in Figure 3, the ultimate load curve in a RTP program in a smart grid environment is much smoother with a high load factor which shows the efficient operation of a smart power grid.

The smoother load curve in a smart grid environment leads to a smoother price curve consequently. Moreover, energy has a cheaper price during the day, and also price volatility and price spikes are effectively eliminated. Figure 4 compares the initial price curve, price curve after the execution of a TOU program, and the price curve using a RTP program in a smart grid environment. As can be seen in Figure 4, a smart grid has helped the system to work more efficiently and to provide consumers with lower electricity prices during the day.

sec.title: 10. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, the influences of the execution of a TOU program and RTP program in a smart grid environment have been compared. A method has been introduced in order to select appropriate buses for installing of smart meters. Buses have been selected using a GSF. In order to simulate the effect of TOU and RTP programs on the system’s load curve, a DR model has been used and the effect of a smart grid on this model has been demonstrated. The IEEE 57-bus test system has been selected in order to analyze the proposed method and to investigate the effect of TOU and RTP programs. Eventually, these two programs have been compared with respect to load shape modification, load factor, price curve, and EPNS.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Hassan Monsef received his BSc (1986) from Sharif University of Technology, his MSc (1989) with honors from the University of Tehran, and his PhD (1996) from Sharif University of Technology, all in power engineering. After being with Electric Power Research Center as a senior engineer from 1992 to 1997, he joined the Faculty of Engineering in the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Tehran, where he is currently an associate professor. He served as an invited research professor in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Ryerson University, Canada in 2011-2012. His research interests are power system operation under deregulation, power system reliability and integration of renewable energy sources into a smart grid.

Bin Wu graduated from Donghua University, Shanghai, China, in 1978 and received his MASc and PhD degrees in electrical and computer engineering from the University of Toronto, Canada, in 1989 and 1993, respectively. After being with Rockwell Automation as a senior engineer from 1992 to 1993, he joined Ryerson University, where he is currently a professor and NSERC/Rockwell Industrial Research Chair. He has published more than 200 technical papers, authored a Wiley-IEEE Press book, and holds over 20 issued and pending patents in the areas of power electronics, adjustable-speed drives and renewable energy systems. He was a guest editor of IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics special section on high power drives in 2007 and is currently an associate editor of IEEE Canadian Review. He has served as an associate editor of IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics since 2005.
